Title: GIS based earthquake potential analysis in Northwest Himalayan, Pakistan
Authors: Ahmed, T., Rehman, K., Shafique, M., & Ali, W.
Overview: Construct an earthquake potential for Nepal map by integrating multiple data sources using GIS

Title: Quantifying urban forest structure with open-access remote sensing data sets
Authors: Baines, O., Wilkes, P., & Disney, M.
Overview: Estimating three metrics of 3D forest structure (canopy cover, canopy height and tree density) across the Greater London area

Title: Influence of built environment on pedestrian crashes: A network-based GIS analysis
Overview: A network-based kernel density technique was used to locate the hotspots of pedestrian crashes. An environmental audit was then conducted to provide a qualitative assessment of the built environment within each hotspot. Bivariate analysis and negative binomial models were utilized to examine the influence quantitatively after the road was partitioned into short road segments.
Technique(s): Network analysis; Network based kernel density estimates
Notes: Ignore public audit portion of the analysis

Title: Applied soft classes and fuzzy confusion in a patchwork semi-arid ecosystem: Stitching together classification techniques to preserve ecologically-meaningful information
Authors: Enterkine, J., Caughlin, T. T., Dashti, H., & Glenn, N. F.
Overview: k-means clustering to establish soft classes of vegetation cover communities from detailed field observations. A time-series of Sentinel-2 satellite imagery and a random forest classification leverages the mixing of different phenologies over time to impute such soft community classes over the landscape.

Title: Petrochemical releases disproportionately affected socially vulnerable populations along the Texas Gulf Coast after Hurricane Harvey
Authors: Flores, A. B., Castor, A., Grineski, S. E., Collins, T. W., & Mullen, C.
Overview: We calculated a Hurricane Harvey petrochemical hazard density index (PHDI) based on the locations of 42 facilities with reported releases along the Texas Gulf Coast. We used sociodemographic data from the American Community Survey to examine census tract-level social inequalities in PHDI
Technique(s): Buffer; x/y point creation; area calculation;
Notes: Intermediate level GIS analysis followed by advanced level regression modelling

Title: The spatio-temporal impacts of demolition land use policy and crime in a shrinking city
Authors: Frazier, A. E., Bagchi-Sen, S., & Knight, J.
Overview: Demolition of abandoned buildings hotspots are used to determine effects on hotspot patterns and directional change of three types of crimes associated with abandoned buildings
Technique(s): Mean Center; Getis-Ord Hotspot; Determining neighborhood

Title: An ecological study on the spatially varying relationship between county-level suicide rates and altitude in the United States
GIS investigation of the fire history of Jonkershoek Nature Reserve
Overview: Image classification was carried out from 2005 to 2015 to determine the burn patterns, with the process being aided by the fire regime history from 1970 to 2015. Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) analysis was carried out to determine how abiotic factors, such as elevation, slope and aspect, impact fires in the Reserve. The assessment of fires included the ascertainment of their location, coverage, and frequency, the Normalised Burn Ratio (NBR), the differenced Normalised Burn Ratio (dNBR) and the Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI)
Notes: Methods are not complicated, but minimal information is provided about data and procedures

Title: Using Zillow data to value green space amenities at the neighborhood scale
Authors: Holt, J. R., & Borsuk, M. E.
Overview: Analyze over 5000 Zillow neighborhoods located in metropolitan areas across 44 states to identify the marginal value of urban green spaces with respect to median neighborhood home prices
Technique(s): vector and raster processing; NDVI; regression; Moran I

Title: Analysis of COVID-19 Cases' Spatial Dependence in US Counties Reveals Health Inequalities
Authors: Saffary, T., Adegboye, O. A., Gayawan, E., Elfaki, F., Kuddus, M. A., & Saffary, R.
Overview: Spatial clustering analysis f Covid-19 cases
Technique(s): Descriptive statistics; Global Moran's I; Local Moran's I

Title: Evaluating social vulnerability indicators: criteria and their application to the Social Vulnerability Index
Authors: Spielman, S. E., Tuccillo, J., Folch, D. C., Schweikert, A., Davies, R., Wood, N., & Tate, E.
Overview: Multiple SoVI-based measurements of the vulnerability of the same place, using the same data, can yield strikingly different results. Authors also show that the SoVI is often misaligned with theory; increases in variables that contribute to vulnerability, like the unemployment rate, often decrease vulnerability as measured by the SoVI.
Notes: Reproduction includes updated code in a computational notebook

Title: Mapping urbanization trends in a forested landscape using Google Earth Engine
Authors: Zurqani, H. A., Post, C. J., Mikhailova, E. A., & Allen, J. S.
Overview: Determine the classes and the distribution of land cover using classification of high-resolution satellite imagery for the upstate region of South Carolina and identify urbanization trends.

Title: Rapidly measuring spatial accessibility of COVID-19 healthcare resources: a case study of Illinois, USA
Authors: Kang, J. Y., A. Michels, F. Lyu, Shaohua Wang, N. Agbodo, V. L. Freeman, and Shaowen Wang.
Overview: The original paper is an implementation of the enhanced two-step floating catchment area (E2FCA) method of spatial accessibility measurement in health geography applied to accessibility of intensive care unit beds and ventilators in the state of Illinois for vulnerable people aged 50 or over or diagnosed with COVID-19. The study is significant in its use of parallel processing and cyberinfrastructure. implemented on the CyberGISX system,
